June 1, 1975: Fiction
THE MONEYCHANGERS, by Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $10.) The "Airport" et
seq. treatment -- this time applied to banking.
CENTENNIAL, by James Michener.  (Random House, $12.50.) Dioramic historical
novel covering the land and people around Centennial, Colo.
THE PROMISE OF JOY, by Allen Drury. (Doubleday, $10.) More implausible
Washington melodrama; featuring the "yellow peril" no less.
SHARDIK, by Richard Adams. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95). Adams's storytelling
genius comes a cropper in this fable about a giant bear-god.
SPINDRIFT, by Phyllis A. Whitney. (Doubleday, $7.95.) The old reliable of the
modern Gothic performing to form.
THE MASSACRE AT FALL CREEK, by Jessamyn West. (Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $8.95.) Finely drawn characters, compelling story about whites on trial
for Indian murders in frontier Indiana.
THE SEVEN-PER-CENT SOLUTION, edited by Nicholas Meyer.  (Dutton, $6.95.)
Droll resurrection of Sherlock Holmes, in which he kicks cocaine, foils a grand plot
against world peace.
THE DREADFUL LEMON SKY, by John D, MacDonald. (Lippincott, $6.95.) Travis
McGee again, with MacDonald proving once more he is a fine writer -- period.
A MONTH OF SUNDAYS, by John Updike. (Knopf, $6.95.) Straying parson;
beautifully written but a frail structure for some weighty thoughts.
BLACK SUNDAY, by Thomas Harris (Putnam's, $7.95.) Bludgeoning, topical
thriller about plot to blow up the Super Bowl.
June 1, 1975
Non-Fiction
THE BERMUDA TRIANGLE, by Charles Berlitz. (Doubleday, $7.95.) Uncritical
theorizing about allegedly mysterious ship-plane disappearances.
THE ASCENT OF MAN,  by J. Bronowski. (Little, Brown, $15.) Instructive lecture
course on the evolution of science and technology.
HERE AT THE NEW YORKER, by Brendan Gill. (Random House, $12.95.) Witty
anecdotal history of the magazine's first 50 years.
TOTAL FITNESS, by Laurence E. Morehouse and Leonard Gross. (Simon &
Schuster, $6.95.) Twelve hours to a better body is the claim.
BREACH OF FAITH, by Theodore H. White. (Atheneum $10.95.) The unraveling
of the President, post-1972.
CONVERSATIONS WITH KENNEDY, by Benjamin C. Bradlee. (Norton, $7.95.)
J.F.K. off-camera - witty, profane, with an eye for pretty girls.
HELTER SKELTER, by Vincent Bugliosi with Curt Gentry. (Norton, $10.)
Authoritative account of the Manson family murders and trial.
THE BANKERS, by Martin Mayer. (Weybright and Talley, $15.) Comprehensive,
fact-laden look at banking, lacking in daily-life relevance.
TM: Discovering Inner Energy and Overcoming Stress, by Harold H. Bloomfield,
Michael Peter Cain and Dennis T. Jaffe. (Delacorte, $8.95.) The theory and
practice of Transcendental Meditation.
KATE: The Life of Katherine Hepburn, by Charles Higham. (Norton, $7.95.) Good
try at biography of the elusive actress.
